title: Navigating the X-ray Computed Tomography Landscape: Tools and Techniques for 3D and 4D Imaging
content: Since its initial development and demonstration by G. N. Hounsfield in the early 1970’s [1, 2], X-ray computed tomography (XCT) has proven to be an important imaging tool for a variety of scientific disciplines. Three-dimensional (3D), spatially resolved images are acquired nondestructively and provide an inside view of the imaged object. With the development of X-ray optics, high-resolution cameras, and high precision motorized stages, XCT can be extended from its original macro-scale resolutions to micrometer (micro-XCT) and 10’s of nanometer (nano-XCT) resolutions. In addition to spanning several length scales, XCT can span several time scales: termed 4D XCT, this technique can be used to image very slow processes using a laboratory X-ray source or rather fast processes when using a bright X-ray source (i.e., synchrotron radiation).
